Bene, finalmente ho terminato l'ultimo gioco degli Aveyond.

I primi due mi erano piaciuti molto e mi spiace non ci siano su Steam. Purtroppo li presi su Impulse/Gamestop e su Steam la collezione pare monca. Peccato perchè non erano male.
Il terzo è diviso in 4 parti e mi ha deluso moltissimo: ho bocciato tutti e quattro i sottocapitoli, anche per il fatto che hanno diviso in 4 un gioco che come lunghezza era paragonabile ai primi due e al quarto: un completo nonsense. E anche per l'estenuante backtracking.
Per il quarto che dire. Beh, è bellissimo.

Diciamo subito che ci sono state almeno un paio di circostanze in cui ho riso di gusto. Ma non sorridendo, proprio ridendo come un fesso davanti lo schermo. Il protagonista Boyle è un soggettone che vuole fare il cattivone (in passato lo era) ed è promesso sposo ad una strega cattiva (Ingrid): i due si beccano in continuazione durante tutto il gioco, e non solo, ci sono stati momenti con altri personaggi davvero piacevoli, che mi hanno appunto strappato più risate.
Il gioco è lungo (tra 35 e 40 ore se si decide di portare tutte le missioni a termine), anche se per qualche missione permane il problema del backtracking (soprattutto una quest relativa alla formazione di una congrega delle streghe, ma ne vale la pena per avere una maledizione finale che fa un fracco di danni).

Le missioni sono appuntate su un diario e mano a mano che si risolvono vengono cancellate, quindi il tutto è molto pulito e ordinato. Anche se l'uso dell'inventario per gestire gli oggetti è molto scomodo, perchè bisogna scorrerli sempre uno ad uno non potendo gestire le loro priorità (ad esempio, se durante un combattimento un personaggio muore bisogna scorrere tutti gli oggetti per trovare quello che permette la resurrezione e questo viene messo in fondo alla lista).

C'è molto di avventura grafica oltre ai combattimenti, con enigmi (bella la parte dentro il castello in cui bisogna capire cosa fare per procedere tra le stanze inizialmente inibite) e la disposizione dei mondi verso cui viaggiare è abbastanza intelligente, anche se a volte si dimenticano i nomi delle locazioni e si fa fatica a ricordare dove andare. Ma c'è anche una specie di netherworld che permette di fare viaggi veloci e leggere i nomi delle locazioni di arrivo su comodi cartelli. Verso la fine si sblocca anche la nave e si può anche viaggiare liberamente.

A parte il backtraking (che per questa tipologia di gioco è sempre presente e a volte è snervante perchè alcuni passaggi sono labirintici e si vorrebbe evitare di rifarli più volte) evidenzio tre altri difetti:

1- le missioni secondarie sono piacevoli, ma a volte lo sforzo non dà grandi soddisfazioni finali, o perchè l'oggetto acquisito è inutile o perchè magari in precedenza si era già presa un'arma (o armatura) potente in un'altra missione e ci si ritrova come premio di missione qualcosa di più scarso. Inoltre le missioni non rilasciano esperienza: secondo me avrebbero dovuto implementarla. Anche perchè...

2- la sezione finale è davvero sproporzionata in quanto a difficoltà rispetto il resto del gioco (non impareranno mai a gestire questo aspetto, mai). In genere combattimenti contro nemici nuovi e boss sono piacevoli e ben misurati, ma poi si arriva sulla Montagna del Teschio e si scopre di avere di fronte nemici troppo OverPowered, boss finale compreso. Qui ho faticato un po', e sono stato costretto a tornare indietro per finire altre missioni, trovando armature migliori, e livellare maggiormente.

3- la trama generale non è proprio chiara e nel complesso non ha molto mordente. Per fortuna Boyle ed Ingrid tengono alto lo spirito dell'avventura.

Belle le locazioni, belle alcune pensate (interruttori che modificano ad esempio la conformazione di un livello) e bella la sequenza finale (con battuta epica finale di Boyle) in cui si inserisce anche una sequenza che dipende dalla romance intrapresa durante il gioco. C'è pure la cosa scema a chiudere.

Lo consiglio vivamente, lo ritengo l'episodio più riuscito tra i quattro Aveyond.

8/10

As a life-long fan of the Aveyond series, I can say with certainty that this is an incredible game. However, it's not an Aveyond game. Yes there are references here and there in conversation, but the only thing that makes this game by definition an Aveyond game is the presence of the holy land of Aveyond itself. You could change the name of that place and erase the 5 or 6 references you get in passing and you wouldn't even know it was part of the series. Like I said before I don't think this is a bad game, but it just doesn't have the feeling of being on a proper quest to save the world. In every Aveyond prior to this, there has been a real threat of an evildoer plotting some grand plan, and you are sent on a quest to stop this from happening, running into all sorts of plot twists, tricky puzzles and difficult enemies along the way. In this game, [spoiler] you start off on a quest to find your dog, and even when the game seems to pull out the dramatic plot of an evil demon, [/spoiler] the main characters brush it off as a joke, leaving the whole plot lacking to feel of a real, important goal.

Another aspect of the game that I believe sets it aside for the rest of the series is the amount of consistencies of the series that were broken:
[list]
[*]There is little to no mention of Thais or the Pendragons
[*]The menus work in a completely different way (i.e. no numbers on health/mana bars when using items, an individual equip menu for every character in their profile instead of one equip menu for everyone, the unappealing new layout of the home menu (especially when trying to use keys to quickly navigate the screen) etc.)
[*]New interactions with spells (i.e. a spell may hit a random number of times, hit a random enemy/random enemies, hit the hero party etc).
[*]Plently of memorable item, monster and character sprites were removed (which seems petty, but alongside everything else it kind of just sealed the deal)
[/list]
I feel like any one of these things could be implemented without alienating the game from the series, but all 3 along with others I might not have said are definitely a rather large shock.

As I have already eluded to, I also believe this game relies too much on it's comedic value to hold the player's interest in the plot (and the game as a whole). I had my fair share of good laughs during the Orbs of Magic series (usually during exchanges between Te'ijal and Galahad), and yes they made the games all the more enjoyable and added a sense of personality to the characters, but what keeps me going back to those games (as well as Aveyond 1 and 2) is the sense of completion I get every time I complete a quest, defeat a difficult enemy or ultimately finish the game. But because of all the satire and lack of suspense as to the final boss' plans, I found myself at the end of this game without even realising it. The feeling of approaching the climax of the story (i.e. the final showdown to stop your enemy's plan once and for all) just wasn't there. The fact that so many quests are left out of your journal for you to figure out on your own (i.e. [spoiler] the whole ordeal involving the two wizards and their towers [/spoiler]) didn't help either, as I went into the final fight fully expecting futher story development involving those side quests that I had assumed would come up later. (Please note that I am not saying the unwritten side quests were a negative addition. They are a great source of replay value and add that extra sense of completion to the game. However they should probably be pushed further to the side so as to not interfere with the apparent progression of the main storyline, or else they may actually withdraw from the sense of completion as it did with me).

Another note that I should make is that the number of highly problematic bugs in the game (at least at the time I played it) is rather alarming. Some characters don't show up during cutscenes, images may be doubled (i.e. [spoiler] a tile showing glowing eyes in a hollow tree shows a duplicate beneath itself on the misty mountain as the start of the game [/spoiler] ). And even carrying certain items interfered with menu interactions.

I love the Aveyond series dearly, and I did thoroughly enjoy this game. I did get a good sense of completion for all the quests I finished and secrets i found. However, it just doesn't fit the epic fantasy adventure RPG role that the series demands of any addition. I find it to be more of a sort of parody of the series. My overall rating for the game (based on satisfaction) would be about 6/10.

I have played all the Aveyond games and I have loved them all... except for this one. That's not to say it isn't an okay game, but it didn't live up to the expectations I have come to have for an Aveyond game. It was a bit disappointing.

Pros:

 - The art is, as usual, beautiful. Each location has so many little details that make the map come alive.

 - The humor is on point.
 - Lots of little easter eggs / throwbacks to previous Aveyond games.

Cons:
 - The quests were all over the place, to the point it became confusing in parts. While a game can be boring if it is too linear, this game would have benefitted from more clear direction.
 - The story started out strong, but fell apart toward the middle. 
 - Backtracking. A lot of tedious back and forth, zig zagging all over. It got pretty boring.
 - The locations, while beautiful, felt small and cramped. The overall world map felt like each continent / island was stuck together on a too-small map at the end. Where previous games felt open and vast, this one felt small and squished.
 - The ending. No spoilers, but it was a letdown. I kept saying to myself "That's it?". Pretty disappointing.

Overall, the game started out strong but seemed to lose it's way around the middle. I enjoyed it for the most part, but I felt as though the game had potential to be better than it was. If you love the Aveyond games, by all means get the game. Maybe wait until it's on sale though.

很久之前就接触 Aveyond 系列的游戏，玩第一部的时候觉得还不错，经过这么多年已经出到第四部了。

第三部到第四部之间隔的时间真得挺久的，不知道什么时候开始官网上的 Aveyond 4 就一直写着 Coming Soon，经过这么多年终于新鲜出炉了，作为老玩家表示这一代的 Aveyond 绝对是厚积薄发，没有让我失望！

在主线剧情方面上 Aveyond 4 延续了前作的风格，有经典 JRPG 的特点，并且[b]依然[/b]是主角拯救世界。不过故事展开的方式有了一些变化，主角不像是前作那样出身于普通人，而是征服世界未遂的 Boyle the Horrible。故事在散播正能量的同时也有很强的讽刺意味，打算征服世界的 Boyle 和拯救世界的英雄 Herclues 的实际身份完全反了过来。不得不再一次感叹编剧的想象力。

但是感觉 Aveyond 系列的气氛慢慢由严肃转为逗比，在 Aveyond 3 以后更是如此。在看 Aveyond 4 开场动画的时候笑出声，并不是因为它真的幽默，而是感觉一开始的 Boyle 作为反派，给人一种“坏到傻”的感觉。剧情中的角色也会不分场合地开各种玩笑，就连国王都是一副不正经的样子。这让我感觉是在看一出闹剧，虽然很欢乐，但是感觉总是不对。相比之下我还是喜欢 Aveyond 1 的那种严肃向的感觉。

人物刻画方面做得很不错，Boyle 和 Ingrid 这一对冤家简直太逗了，还有 Robin 这个年轻的骑士简直就是傻白甜。剧情中的 NPC 也是非常有趣的，而且不同地区的 NPC 的性格非常不同，这也是 Aveyond 系列的一大特色，希望能继续保持下去。

游戏细节部分制作得非常好，首先地图画质上和 3 代相比有了巨大的提升，并且也加了很多“特技”，人物行走图上还有一些细微动作，感觉到了良心。我非常喜欢 Windy Hills 那里的吊索桥的设计，主角走上去桥会微微晃动一下，感觉很逼真。人物经过不同区域的行走速度都会发生变化，爬梯子人会背过身去，还有脚步声的细节，都非常不错。

Aveyond 4 的可玩性非常高，并且我感觉它的解谜成分是所有 Aveyond 系列中最多的，皇宫地下洞窟的迷宫设计得很棒，精灵村图书馆的解谜也很有趣，相比于 Aveyond 1 里面吸血鬼村的那几个猜谜，简直好太多了。战斗系统也是改进了许多，我记得 3 代之前的回合制几乎没有任何的改动，到了 4 代战斗系统终于改了，加了一些新奇的玩法，我想说这不是早就应该这么做了么……支线的任务也蛮丰富的，奖励也不错，最后，好感度系统依然是那么简陋。另外这游戏像 Aveyond 3-4 一样，金钱资源非常稀少，十分考验大家的经济头脑。

说句题外话，Aveyond 4 里面的很多内容都和前作有关系，可能是向前作致敬，不过也可能是制作组在偷懒。但是无论如何，Aveyond 4 如果在玩前作的梗的话，那么刚接触此作品的玩家就会一脸懵逼。首先，依然是万年老梗 Te'ijal 和 Galahad，他们两位出现在 Aveyond [b]所有[/b]系列当中，虽然我承认我比较喜欢 T 姐和 G 叔（称呼好像有什么不对），但是，你们能不能换一些人来客串？[strike]我知道过了这么久了能活下来的只有他俩，别人都老死了[/strike]还有就是 Two-Card Flip Game 里面的卡牌，虽然我玩到最后也不知道这游戏到底该怎么玩，但是里面的卡牌多数借鉴了 Aveyond 3 的人物，例如 Mel, Edward, Gyendal 等。还有 Robin 商店任务里的某个顾客说她怀念 Shaenir 的天气，Shaenir 其实是 Aveyond 2 里面唯一的一个北方城市。总之看到这些梗老玩家表示很亲切，新玩家就算是懵逼也不太影响对剧情的理解吧（大概

好了下面说说 Aveyond 4 的问题。首先我玩通关之后表示剧情气氛是个硬伤，这部游戏从头到尾所有的角色几乎都在讲笑话，这真不是件好事情。然后就是主线里面有某些严重拖延剧情的现象，虽然有传送系统但是主角的移动速度真是太慢了，还是有很多时间花在了跑路上（雾灵妹子上下梯子不减速我也是才知道的）。这个游戏我卡过一次关，就是在解救 Hi'beru 返回 Tor 那里。说实话我真没找到第二个大陆的 Port 在哪，后来一顿瞎找终于在一个很[spoiler]哔[/spoiler]的地方找到了那个 Port 我想说制作组你们是不是故意把 Port 画成那样好让我们看不见的？

总之，Aveyond 4 是一款非常棒的游戏，无论新玩家还是老玩家，都值得去体验一下。

I have been a long-time fan of all the Aveyond games--they've followed me through childhood--and playing Aveyond 4 as an adult has been a great way to come back to the series. Each of the games is their own experience, and while in certain narrative ways Aveyond 4 feels like a regression, as far as gameplay goes, the series has grown in some fantastic ways. Though I feel as though the protagonist was the wrong choice for this game, the game maps are extensive and rewarding, and the arc of the game is smooth and fulfilling. The way the game plays is excellent, and the narrative aspect mostly provides context for how to view it, so although I was largely disappointed in the story of the game, I loved Aveyond 4 as a whole.

Overall, I had a great experience and would wholly recommend it. That said, this review is largely narrative critique. 

THE NARRATIVE:

Narratively, Boyle felt like the wrong choice for the protagonist. He is not engaging as a main character--the humor regarding 'retired villains' and 'heroes' fell flat, and it felt reductive. The best part about him was his relationship with his dog, but that dedication is not enough to make a protagonist. An attempt at humor regarding evildoing in a comical tone is not enough to make a protagonist, either. While the backstory about how he found his dog as a pup was touching, it does not offer strong enough motive for him to be the main character of this story. He is mostly a static character. While he does admit that doing good is pretty good, it is dulled by the joke of it all, and the retired supervillain aspect diminishes the entire relationship of good and evil. Basically, it seems as though he was truly good all along, and the only amount of growth is in his awareness of this, and it is not enough to drive an entire game. His personal stake in this journey is not, narratively, the strongest one.

Boyle is looking for his dog; Myst is looking for her brother. In order to find his dog, Boyle must find Myst's brother, who was snatched by a demon. Even the game's title, "Shadow Of The Mist", suggests that Myst is the one with more to lose, here. Boyle plays the reluctant hero, but it is irritating to have what feels so much like Myst's story filtered through this flat, reductive joke of a retired supervillain. Myst has never been away from the mountain, and while she also needs to find her little brother, she longs to see the sights outside of The Mist. She has so much to learn, so far to go. She has the most reason to go on this journey to defeat the demon and save her brother, and she has the farthest to grow. She is the most dynamic character, at a tipping point of her life.

If Myst were the main character, the framing of this game would've been much more powerful--and it would've offered a kind of serious beauty to it, too. In that way, it would mirror Aveyond 2, which was personally an extremely successful, gorgeous game with a very gentle, fairy-tale like story. This still would've been light-hearted in (many ways, and a grand heartfelt adventure, but it would've also had the background context of a fairy-tale. This game could've so easily been absolutely incredible, beautiful, had Myst been the protagonist. She has every reason to be. Also, her background as a Myst Wraith is so much more compelling than the dull, simplifying joke of the Retired Supervillain.

THE GAMEPLAY: 

The maps are beautiful. They are detailed, extensive, and so very rewarding. The chests are set up so that they can be seen when strolling on the most obvious paths, and while it does take some challenge to look for them, it is not to the point of frustration. Taking the effort to go the long way around for a chest that was seen ten minutes earlier is always worth the effort. The color schemes of the maps are brilliant, well-thought, and the layouts of all the buildings are varied, textured, not tired and reused. Each part of the journey has its own distinctive map which feels like its own little area within a larger world, which helps create a better idea of this lush, full world of Aveyond. The only complaint here is that some of the maps are so ambitious that they lag on soe systems. I also loved how purposeful all the sidequests were; everything was important.

The battle system is set up in a spin of the traditional turn-based system. It makes battles so much less tedious. Each character has a different role in battle, with their own pros and cons, and it is very fun to think about how best to use each character. Myst has a few different abilities, including a healing and shapeshifting one, and using these abilities does not require a cost of mana or skill point, although it does mean that these abilities aren't as powerful as ones that would have a cost. Boyle's darkness points are replenished with physical attacks, and he uses these same points to cast magic, and it is very fun to have a wizard type who is also a formidable physical attacker--in addition to his minion, whose attacks add additional damage at every turn. Those are only two of the characters, but all of them have roles that aren't so simple as deducting a mana / skill point cost. The character battle roles are fun, and the battles demand a measure of attention that makes it so they aren't a matter of grinding through the same predictable battle rhythm again and again. It's more fluid than that.

The only thing I would say is that there are many characters who get introduced too late in the game to really develop an affection for them, or a feel for their role in battle, so they don't get the opportunity to shine. It's more difficult to care about them, when there is so little time to get familiar with them.

LASTLY:

In a lot of ways, I do not think Aveyond is the right arena to even attempt deconstructing Heroes or Villains--that seems more the space of cape comics and games inspired by those. It felt odd and uncomfortable to reference that type of Hero vs. Villain relationship in a largely original, fantastical world such as Aveyond. Also uncomfortable in the game was the way sprites from popular anime series appeared in prominent side quest characters, as if, no one would notice Hetalia sprites or Chi from Chobits acting in ways that seemed to serve no purpose, no reference, to their original series at all. It was not right to include representations of those licensed designs in this original game being sold for its own profit. Original sprites should have been made by the Aveyond team. Both of these aspects broke immersion of Aveyond as the world of Aveyond, an original fantasy world with, largely, its own mythos which does at times reference outside ones, like Aveyond 2 and the Snow Queen, and moments like referencing the Fruit of the (Greek) Gods (a pomegranate) in Aveyond 1.  

In terms of media representation, the Aveyond series made such an impact on me as a kid realizing that girls and women were powerful, complex characters, and to see them in positions of power, as heroes unqualified by the acts of men, it was incredible. And honestly, if I wanted to play a game about a man, I'd look literally anywhere else. That was one of the first reasons why Boyle failed as a protagonist for me. He has nothing to add to the conversation. He is not refreshing in any way. There are countless characters like him, and there are so few respectful representations of women in games, especially Fantasy ones known for their trope of women as reward for the (male) hero's triumphs, damsels in distress, or as vile and petty temptations of evil.

All this said: I loved this game. It may be because I played it most recently, but it was my favorite game to play. But, narratively, it doesn't compare with Aveyond 1 or Aveyond 2 and the way those games stayed in my heart. I still had a blast, though, and am looking forward to replaying it

I have long been a fan of the Aveyond games.  However, you do *not* need to have played any of the others to enjoy or understand this game.  There are a couple of long-lived recurring non-playable minor characters from earlier series, but they do not play major roles in this game.  This is also a complete game, unlike the 4-part Aveyond 3.

You can play this with either a keyboard or a mouse.  I generally prefer the keyboard unless I am trying to navigate tricky terrain or avoid a bad guy without a fight.

This is a long, detailed, well-imagined fantasy game.  There are battles, and you can have up to four fighters (plus one minion) from amongst your seven party members (you won't have seven party members the whole game, for most of it you will have fewer than seven).  Each character has different battle skills and strengths, and you may not want the same fighters in every situation.  You will have a chance to experience the battle interface during the demo. 

The party does not always remain the same, either.  Although Boyle is the main character, occasionally other playable characters will have quests without him.   All the characters have unique backgrounds, and many are very different characters than we have seen in previous games.

There is a lot of fun, snarky humor in this game, especially with two of the MCs (Boyle and Ingrid) being an ex-villain and a witch.  Possibly reformed characters make great reluctant heroes.   Boyle's primary loyalty is to his dog/wolf Fang.  It takes him a while to get used to being part of a group.

I don't want to give away much of the plot, but there many different locations in this expansive world, allowing for many different creatures and scenery.  (Mountains, forest, farmland, desert, seaside mining town, swamp, dreamscape, etc).  There are a bunch of main quests, and a fair number of optional side-quests with useful rewards.

There are several options for replayability, too, especially involving Ingrid, who can marry one of several men, depending on who she fancies and how much work she puts into it, and also join one of three witches covens, each with its own unique spells.  Eventually I want to try al the options.

So, try the demo and see if this is the sort of game you like.  (Note: the first half-hour is more scripted than the rest of the game, so do not be misled or turned off by the initial nudging).  

Also, my tip to you - save early and often, especially before battle.  And talk to everyone you encounter.  

I had (and am having) lots of fun with this game and I hope you do too.  In some respects it is like immersing yourself in an interactive book/movie and experiencing a deep and nuanced world.  You might have to put more effort into it that the normal shooter or point-and-click games, but you will be rewarded for your efforts with a unique experience most games do not give you.  Most games are forgettable and interchangeable, but I always remember the Aveyond games and characters long after I am done playing.  Aveyond 4 makes me smile and forget about the real world for a while.
